facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 3, 1964 by GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J.

anchor.surface_text: February 3, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J.-This appeal by special leave raises a short question about the true scope and effect of section 52A of the Sea Customs Act, 1878

facts.text: Appellant Indo-China Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. owns motor vessel Eastern Saga.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Indo- China Steam Navigation Co. Ltd., which carries on the business of carriage of goods and passengers by sea, owns a fleet of ships, and has been carrying on its business for over 80 years.

facts.text: Eastern Saga has 6,631 gross registered tons, 4,441 net registered tons, length 475-2-1/2, breadth 59-3, summer draft 24-7.

anchor.surface_text: The vessel Eastern Saga has 6,631 gross registered tons, and 4,441 net registered tons. It has an overall length of 475-2-1/2 a breadth of 59-3 and a summer draft of 24-7.

facts.text: Eastern Saga arrived at Calcutta from the Far East on October 29, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Eastern Saga arrived at Calcutta from the Far East on October 29, 1957. In the companyrse of its ordinary voyage, as a cargo vessel carrying, a legitimate cargo of 24,815 packages of general merchandise weighing 1,506 tons,

facts.text: Vessel carrying legitimate cargo of 24,815 packages of general merchandise weighing 1,506 tons.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of its ordinary voyage, as a cargo vessel carrying, a legitimate cargo of 24,815 packages of general merchandise weighing 1,506 tons, it was rummaged by Calcutta Customs Officers

facts.text: Calcutta Customs Officers rummaged the vessel on October 30, 31, and November 12, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: it was rummaged by Calcutta Customs Officers on the 30th and 31st October and on the 12th November, 1957 On search being made of the vessels domestic refrigeration companypartments,

facts.text: Large quantity of gold in bars found in a hole in sailors accommodation behind wooden seat.

anchor.surface_text: The hole opened into a space and in that space, the Customs Officers found a large quantity of gold in bars. Further search in the sailors accommodation led to the discovery of a hole

facts.text: 1,358 gold bars discovered, value approximately Rs. 23,79,490/80 nP.

anchor.surface_text: The quantity of gold found on the vessel was approximately of the value of Rs. 23,79,490/80 nP. Rs. 109/24 nP. per tola, and he numbericed the fact that this was the recovery made

facts.text: Notices to show cause served on November 12, 1957 to owners' agents Jardine Henderson and Co. Ltd., master Captain Kiunear, and crew member Kwok Cho.

anchor.surface_text: On November 12, 1957, numberices were served on the owners Agents at Calcutta, M s. Jardine Henderson and Co. Ltd., and on the master of the vessel, Captain Kiunear, respectively to show cause why the vessel should number be company- fiscated

facts.text: Additional Collector of Customs passed order on November 23, 1957 confiscating vessel under s.167(12A), option to pay fine Rs. 25 lakhs, confiscating gold under s.167(8), penalty Rs.10,000 on Kwok Cho.

anchor.surface_text: on November 23, 1957, he passed the impugned order. He held that having carefully companysidered the written explanations tendered and oral arguments urged before him, he was satisfied that the preventive measures taken by the owners,

facts.text: Appeal to Central Board of Revenue dismissed on May 12, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred an appeal before the Central Board of Revenue. The Board companysidered the matter and came to the companyclusion that numbere of the companytentions raised by the appellant was either warranted or supported by the law as it stands.

facts.text: Revisional application to Government of India dismissed on December 17, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from order No. 1742 of 1960 of the Government of India Ministry of Finance  Department of Revenue  dated December 17, 1960 in Custom Revision Application No. 1631 of 1959

facts.text: Vessel value much more than Rs. 25 lakhs fine.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the value of the ship is very much more than the amount of Rs. 25 lacs imposed by way of fine under s. 183.

facts.text: Court holds Central Board of Revenue and Central Government are Tribunals under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, having regard to the scheme of the sections which we have just cited, there is numberdifficulty in holding that the Central Board of Revenue which functions as an appellate authority, and the Central Government which exercises revi- sional powers are both Tribunals

facts.text: Court finds vessel contravened s.52A by alterations for concealing goods.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, our companyclusion is that the Customs Authorities were right in holding that the facts proved in the case showed that the appellants vessel Eastern Saga companytravened the provisions of s. 52A when it entered the port of Calcutta

facts.text: No mens rea required for contravention of s.52A.

anchor.surface_text: The knowledge of the owners, or even of the master is, in the companytext of s. 52A, entirely irrelevant. What is relevant is the proof of the fact that the vessel answering the description prescribed by s. 52A entered within the limits of Calcutta

facts.text: Appeal dismissed, writ petition No.138/1961 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts. The appellant has also filed W.P. No. 138 of 1961 chal- lenging the validity of the order passed by the Central Gov- ernment in the same matter. Since the appeal preferred by the appellant against the said order is dismissed, the writ petition also fails and is dismissed.

issues.text: What is the true scope and effect of section 52A of the Sea Customs Act, 1878?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises a short question about the true scope and effect of section 52A of the Sea Customs Act, 1878  No. 8 of 1878   hereinafter called the Act .

issues.text: Whether the Central Board of Revenue exercising appellate power under s.190 and Central Government exercising revisional power under s.191 are Tribunals under Art.136?

anchor.surface_text: The question which then arises is, can the Central Board of Revenue exercising its appellate power under s. 190 of the Act, or the Central Government exercising its revisional jurisdiction under s. 191, be held to be a Tribunal under Art. 136?

issues.text: Whether contravention of s.52A requires proof of mens rea on part of owners or master?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Choudhury contends that the contravention of s. 52A cannot be established unless the mens rea is proved against the persons responsible for the alleged contravention.

issues.text: Whether alteration in panelling of vessel constitutes alteration of the vessel attracting s.52A?

anchor.surface_text: the panelling wall in which the apertures were made, cannot be treated as a part of the vessel, and so, the alteration in question cannot be said to attract s. 52A.

issues.text: What is the nature of liability under s.167(12A): is confiscation mandatory or discretionary?

anchor.surface_text: What is the nature of the liability prescribed by s. 167 12A  is the next question which calls for an answer in the present appeal.

issues.answer: mandatory confiscation but option to pay fine under s.183

issues.text: Whether the vessel contravened s.52A on the facts of the case?
Whether the fine of Rs.25 lakhs imposed is excessive?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Choudhary has then argued that the imposition of a fine of Rs. 25 lacs is excessive and should be modified by us.

issues.text: Whether s.52A is ultra vires Articles 14, 19 and 31(1) if mens rea not required?

arguments.claim: None of the Customs Authorities which dealt with the case, including Customs Collector, Central Board of Revenue, or Central Government, is a tribunal under Art. 136(1), so appeal incompetent and special leave should be revoked.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this appeal, the learned Additional Solicitor-General has urged a preliminary objection. He contends that none of the Customs Authorities which had dealt with the appellants case is a tribunal under Art. 136 1  of the Constitution, and so, the appeal preferred by the appellant is incompetent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: l shall be liable to companyfiscation and the master of such vessel shall be liable to a penalty number exceeding Rs. 1,000. It would be numbericed th

arguments.court_reasoning: Scheme of Sea Customs Act invests appellate (s.188,190) and revisional (s.190A,191) authorities with State's judicial power; required to act judicially, follow natural justice; hierarchy for adjudication.

arguments.claim: Contravention of s.52A cannot be established unless mens rea proved against persons responsible; import mens rea as essential element per criminal jurisprudence principles.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Choudhury contends that the contravention of s. 52A cannot be established unless the mens rea is proved against the persons responsible for the alleged contravention. In that connection he has relied on the fact that the section makes no difference between concealed goods which are not contraband and those which are contraband.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 9 and C.A. No. 374/1961 which have been heard along with this appeal and will be dealt with separately . It appears that in that case Sinha J., held t

arguments.court_reasoning: s.52A absolute prohibition on vessel entry if constructed/altered for concealing goods; no 'knowingly/wilfully' unlike other s.167 clauses; policy to curb smuggling where mens rea hard to prove; defeats purpose if required.

arguments.claim: Alteration in panelling wall not an 'alteration' of the vessel under s.52A as panelling not integral/essential part of vessel.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Choudhary further argued that the alteration on which the case against the appellant is based in the present case cannot be said to be an alteration contemplated by s. 52A, because it is not an alteration of the vessel. He suggests that the construction, adaptation, alteration or fitting must be of the vessel as a whole, or, at any rate, of any part of the vessel which can be regarded as its integral or essential part the paneling wall in which the apertures were made, cannot be treated as a part of the vessel,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nsible for them is inspired merely by cupidity because it companyducts its operations solely for the purpose of making profit, and so, it would be ope

arguments.court_reasoning: s.3(f) defines vessel to include anything for conveyance by water; panelling integral part once constructed; Lloyd's certificate opinion untested, irrelevant to s.52A.

arguments.claim: Fine of Rs.25 lakhs imposed under s.183 excessive, unreasonable, vindictive; should be modified; heavy fines affect national trade.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Choudhary has then argued that the imposition of a fine of Rs. 25 lacs is excessive and should be modified by us. He suggests that if such a heavy fine is imposed against a vessel, it may indirectly and eventually affect the trade of the country. Besides, he urges that the fine appears to be so unreasonable that it may be characterised as vindicative.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: even if it has companytravened s. 52A, and in that sense, there would be inequality between the citizen and the foreigner, but that inequality is the

arguments.court_reasoning: Not excessive given gold value (Rs.23 lakhs), multiple alterations, ship value > fine; upheld by appellate/revisional authorities; deterrent needed for smuggling organized for profit.

arguments.claim: If mens rea not essential to s.52A, section ultra vires Arts.14, 19(1)(f), 31(1).
arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant foreign company, no locus under Art.19 (citizens only); Art.14/31 claims depend on Art.19(1)(f); merits not considered.

arguments.claim: Owners/agents/master had no knowledge of holes/gold; took all reasonable precautions per company instructions; impossible to detect without extensive searches.

anchor.surface_text: The master pleaded that he had no knowledge of the presence of gold or unauthorised holes in the ship and had taken all reasonable precautions in accordance with the Companys instructions. ... They also urged that they had no knowledge about the holes or about the gold which was discovered from one of them. They referred to the statement made by Kwok Cho and alleged that the said statement showed that gold could be smuggled by a smuggler without the knowledge of the master and the owners of the ship.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: acter is the subject-matter of the enquiry, is clothed with the trap- pings of a companyrt. Can it companypel witnesses to appear before it and admini

arguments.court_reasoning: Preventive measures proved hopelessly inadequate/ineffective despite explanations.

arguments.claim: Vessel contravened s.52A by alterations/fittings for concealing goods; liable to confiscation under s.167(12A); preventive measures inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: He held that having carefully considered the written explanations tendered and oral arguments urged before him, he was satisfied that the preventive measures taken by the owners, the agents, and the master proved to be hopelessly inadequate and ineffective. ... His conclusion, therefore, was that the vessel had clearly rendered itself liable to confiscation under s. 167 12A  because it had infringed the provisions of s. 52A.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion 183 lays down that whenever companyfiscation is authorised by this Act, the officer adjudicating it shall give the owner of the goods an option t

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts show alterations for concealing goods; gold found confirms purpose; no operational use.

arguments.claim: None of appellant's contentions warranted/supported by law; offence under s.52A proved; fine not excessive given gold quantity/value.

anchor.surface_text: The Board considered the matter and came to the conclusion that none of the contentions raised by the appellant was either warranted or supported by the law as it stands. The Board expressed its concurrence with the conclusions of the Additional Collector that the offence under s. 52A of the Act had been proved,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion 183 lays down that whenever companyfiscation is authorised by this Act, the officer adjudicating it shall give the owner of the goods an option t

arguments.claim: Central Board of Revenue (appellate under s.190) and Central Government (revisional under s.191) are Tribunals under Art.136.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, having regard to the scheme of the sections which we have just cited, there is no difficulty in holding that the Central Board of Revenue which functions as an appellate authority, and the Central Government which exercises revi- sional powers are both Tribunals

arguments.claim: No mens rea/knowledge of owners/master required for s.52A contravention; focuses on vessel characteristics, not persons.

anchor.surface_text: The knowledge of the owners, or even of the master is, in the context of s. 52A, entirely irrelevant. What is relevant is the proof of the fact that the vessel answering the description prescribed by s. 52A entered within the limits of Calcutta

arguments.claim: s.52A plain meaning: prohibits vessel constructed/adapted/altered/fitted for concealing goods from entering Indian ports/customs waters; absolute, proved by alterations for that purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Section 52A provides that no vessel constructed, adapted, altered, or fitted for the purpose of concealing goods shall enter, or be within the limits of any port in India, or the Indian customs waters. ... Therefore, if an alteration in a vessel made for the purpose of concealing goods is proved, the contravention of s. 52A must be inferred.

arguments.claim: Holes in panelling constitute alteration of vessel under s.52A.

anchor.surface_text: The contention which Mr. Choudhary faintly urged before us, that the holes made in the panelling walls do not constitute an alteration at all is, clearly ill- founded, because the manner in which the holes were made and the use which was obviously intended to be made of the said holes, leave no doubt that they constitute alteration within the meaning of s. 52A.

arguments.claim: s.167(12A) mandates confiscation (no discretion) + penalty on master if s.52A contravened; s.183 gives option to pay fine in lieu.

anchor.surface_text: What is the nature of the liability prescribed by s. 167 12A  is the next question which calls for an answer in the present appeal. ... Confiscation of the vessel is the immediate statutory consequence of the finding that an offence under clause 12A is established

arguments.claim: Customs Officer acts quasi-judicially under Sea Customs Act (citing precedents), but not court/tribunal; appeals/revisions change status.

anchor.surface_text: It is settled by decisions of this Court that the Customs Officer who initially acts under s. 167 12A  is not a Court or Tribunal, though ... in adjudicating upon the question as to whether s. 52A has been contravened ... the Customs Officer has to act in a quasi-judicial manner.

arguments.claim: Maqbool Hussain obiter on CBR/CG not judicial not binding as issue not argued.

anchor.surface_text: It would be noticed that the last observation is purely in the nature of an obiter observation because the status of the Central Board of Revenue or the Central Government ... did not fall to be considered in that case, was not argued, and naturally has not been examined

arguments.claim: Harinagar Sugar Mills: test for tribunal - trappings of court + invested with State's judicial power.

anchor.surface_text: In M s. Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sunder Jhun- jhunwala and Others 1  the question raised before this Court was whether the Central Government while exercising its powers under section 111 3  of the Companies Act, 1956 ... is a Tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136, or not.

arguments.claim: Vessel Eastern Saga contravened s.52A on facts: multiple suspicious alterations, gold found confirms concealing purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, our conclusion is that the Customs Authorities were right in holding that the facts proved in the case showed that the appellants vessel Eastern Saga contravened the provisions of s. 52A when it entered the port of Calcutta

arguments.claim: Openings in No.1 Fitter cabin do not attract s.167(12A).

anchor.surface_text: He also upheld their plea that the openings found in the cabin of No. 1 Fitter did not attract the provisions of s. 167 12A .

arguments.claim: Owners not concerned in illegal gold importation under s.167(8).

anchor.surface_text: He accepted their plea that they need not be regarded as persons concerned in the illegal importation of gold into India within the meaning of s. 167 8  of the Act.

arguments.claim: Kwok Cho claimed gold, so penalize him.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, a notice in similar terms was issued to Kwok Cho, a member of the crew of the Eastern Saga who had come forward to claim the gold which was discovered as a result of the search.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: judicial approach? If all or some of the important tests in that behalf are satisfied, the proceedings can be characterised as judicial proceedings an

arguments.court_reasoning: Imposed Rs.10,000 penalty on Kwok Cho.

arguments.claim: Proceedings under Sea Customs Act follow natural justice; quasi-judicial.

anchor.surface_text: is it bound to comply with the rules of natural justice, is it expected to deal with the matters before it fairly, justly and on the merits and not be guided by subjective considerations

holdings.text: The Central Board of Revenue functioning as an appellate authority under s.188,190 and the Central Government exercising revisional powers under s.190A,191 are both Tribunals within the meaning of Art. 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, having regard to the scheme of the sections which we have just cited, there is no difficulty in holding that the Central Board of Revenue which functions as an appellate authority, and the Central Government which exercises revi- sional powers are both Tribunals

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Sea Customs Act creates hierarchy of quasi-judicial authorities invested with State's judicial power; must act judicially, follow natural justice, determine disputes on evidence; applies Harinagar Sugar Mills test distinguishing from initial customs officer.

holdings.text: No mens rea or knowledge of owners or master is required to establish contravention of s.52A; prohibition is absolute against entry of vessel constructed, adapted, altered or fitted for concealing goods.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: s.52A and s.167(12A) lack 'knowingly/wilfully' unlike other clauses; purposive: to curb smuggling where mens rea hard to prove; policy: defeats purpose if required as alterations undetectable.

holdings.text: Contravention of s.52A does not require proof of mens rea against persons responsible.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature deliberately omitted mens rea words present elsewhere in s.167; requiring it would render section nugatory given smuggling organization and detection difficulties.

holdings.text: Alterations in panelling constitute 'alteration' of the vessel under s.52A as panelling is integral part once constructed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(f) defines vessel broadly; panelling once installed is integral; Lloyd's certificate opinion untested and irrelevant to s.52A purpose; holes' manner/use clearly alteration for concealment.

holdings.text: The vessel Eastern Saga contravened s.52A by alterations made for purpose of concealing goods, as evidenced by multiple holes and discovery of gold bars.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower authorities' findings on inadequate precautions, nature of alterations (no operational purpose), gold discovery confirm concealing intent; applies s.52A to facts.

holdings.text: Under s.167(12A), confiscation of vessel contravening s.52A is mandatory with no discretion to refrain; s.183 requires option to pay fine in lieu, quantum discretionary considering circumstances.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of cl.12A uses 'shall be liable'; no extenuating circumstances exception; independent penalties; s.183 brings discretion via fine option to avoid hardship.

holdings.text: Fine of Rs.25 lakhs in lieu of confiscation is not excessive or unreasonable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proportional to gold value (Rs.23L), multiple alterations, ship value >> fine; upheld by appellate/revisional; deterrent needed for organized profit-driven smuggling.

precedents.citation: Shewpujanrai Indrasanarai Ltd. v. Collector of Customs and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: In Shewpujanrai Indrasanarai Ltd. v. Collector of Customs and Others 1  this Court has held that an order of companyfiscation or penalty passed under the Sea Customs Act is number a mere administrative or executive act, but is really a quasi- judicial act, and, therefore, an application for a writ of certiorari lies in respect of such order under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Shewpujanrai Indrasanarai Ltd v Collector of Customs
precedents.cited_proposition: order of confiscation or penalty passed under the Sea Customs Act is not a mere administrative or executive act, but is really a quasi-judicial act

precedents.citation: F. N. Roy v. Collector of Customs, Calcutta,  2

anchor.surface_text: vide F. N. Roy v. Collector of Customs, Calcutta,  2  and Lea Roy Frey v. The Superintendent, District Jail, Amritsar and Anr. 3 . Similarly, in Thomas Dana v. State of Punjab, 1  this Court has observed that the Collector and other Officers in the hierarchy mentioned by the Sea Customs Act may have to act judicially in the sense of having to consider evidence and hear arguments in an informal way even so, the Act does not contemplate that in doing so, the said authorities are functioning as a Court.

precedents.case_name: FN Roy v Collector of Customs Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: Collector acts judicially in proceedings under the Sea Customs Act

precedents.citation: Lea Roy Frey v. The Superintendent, District Jail, Amritsar and Anr. 3

anchor.surface_text: vide F. N. Roy v. Collector of Customs, Calcutta,  2  and Lea Roy Frey v. The Superintendent, District Jail, Amritsar and Anr. 3 . Similarly, in Thomas Dana v. State of Punjab, 1  this Court has observed that the Collector and other Officers in the hierarchy mentioned by the Sea Customs Act may have to act judicially

precedents.case_name: Lea Roy Frey v Superintendent District Jail Amritsar
precedents.cited_proposition: Collector acts judicially in proceedings under the Sea Customs Act

precedents.citation: Thomas Dana v. State of Punjab, 1

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Thomas Dana v. State of Punjab, 1  this Court has observed that the Collector and other Officers in the hierarchy mentioned by the Sea Customs Act may have to act judicially in the sense of having to consi

precedents.case_name: Thomas Dana v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Collector and other officers act judicially but not as a Court

precedents.citation: Maqbool Hussain v. The State of Bombay etc., 1

anchor.surface_text: In Maqbool Hussain v. The State of Bombay etc., 1  while dealing with the impact of the confiscation of goods under the relevant provisions of s. 167 of the Act on the question as to the constitutionality of a subsequent prosecution launched against a person whose goods had been confiscated, this Court had occasion to consider the effect of the order of confiscation in relation to the provisions of Art. 20 Of the Constitution, and it was held that the proceeding before the Sea Customs Authorities under the Act was not a prosecution and the order of confiscation was not a punishment inflicted by a Court or Judicial Tribunal within the meaning of Art. 20 2 ,

precedents.case_name: Maqbool Hussain v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: proceeding before Sea Customs Authorities is not a prosecution and order of confiscation not punishment by judicial tribunal

precedents.citation: M s. Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sunder Jhunjhunwala and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: In M s. Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sunder Jhun- jhunwala and Others 1  the question raised before this Court was whether the Central Government while exercising its powers under section 111 3  of the Companies Act, 1956  No. 1 of 1956  is a Tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136, or not.

precedents.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd v Shyam Sunder Jhunjhunwala
precedents.cited_proposition: Central Government under s.111 Companies Act is a Tribunal under Art.136

precedents.citation: Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India and Ors., 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of the view taken on this point, this Court referred to an earlier decision in Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India and Ors., 1  where it was held that the Central Government exercising power of review under r. 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 against an administrative order of the State Government granting a mining lease was subject to the appellate jurisdiction of this Court, because the power to review was judicial and not administrative.

precedents.case_name: Shivji Nathubhai v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Central Government review power under Mineral Concession Rules is judicial

precedents.citation: Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd., Meerut Lakshmi Chand and Ors.  2

anchor.surface_text: As illustrations of cases where the application of the said tests leads to the conclusion that certain authorities cannot be held to be tribunals, we may refer to the decisions of this Court in Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd., Meerut Lakshmi Chand and Ors.  2  and Engineering Mazdoor Sabhaand Anr.v.Hind Cycles Ltd. 3 .

precedents.case_name: Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd v Lakshmi Chand

precedents.citation: Engineering Mazdoor Sabhaand Anr.v.Hind Cycles Ltd. 3

anchor.surface_text: Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd., Meerut Lakshmi Chand and Ors.  2  and Engineering Mazdoor Sabhaand Anr.v.Hind Cycles Ltd. 3 . It is in the light of these decisions that we will proceed to consider whether the Central Board of Revenue and the Central Government can be said to be a Tribunal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Engineering Mazdoor Sabha v Hind Cycles Ltd

precedents.citation: Ravula Hariprasada Rao v. The State 1

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that in Ravula Hariprasada Rao v. The State 1 , this Court speaking through Fazl Ali J., has accepted the observations made by the Lord Chief Justice of England in Brend v. Wood 1  that it is of the utmost importance for the protection of the liberty of the subject that a Court should always bear in mind that unless the statute, either clearly or by necessary implication, rules out mens rea as a constituent part of a crime, a defendant should not be found guilty of an offence against the criminal law unless he has got a guilty mind.

precedents.cited_proposition: mens rea presumed unless statute excludes it

anchor.surface_text: observations made by the Lord Chief Justice of England in Brend v. Wood 1  that it is of the utmost importance for the protection of the liberty of the subject that a Court should always bear in mind that unless the statute, either clearly or by necessary implication, rules out mens rea as a constituent part of a crime, a defendant should not be found guilty of an offence against the criminal law unless he has got a guilty mind.  vide also Sherras v. De Rutzen 3 .

precedents.cited_proposition: mens rea is essential unless excluded by statute

anchor.surface_text: vide also Sherras v. De Rutzen 3 . It may also be conceded that offences in respect of which mens rea is not required to be established, are usually of a comparatively minor character and sentences imposed against the offenders are, therefore, not of a severe type

precedents.cited_proposition: mens rea presumed in criminal offences
